awd_titl_txt: Visual Attention and Categorization in Infancy
awd_abstract_narration:
Categorization allows us to make sense of the world. Discovering how infants develop the ability to categorize is important for advancing scientific knowledge about early cognitive development. This project will analyze the rapid development of categorization that occurs in mid- to late-infancy. Multiple measures will be used to determine: (1) the effects of attention on categorization in early development, and (2) areas of the brain involved in categorization in infancy. This research will illuminate how attention influences infant categorization and will use neuroimaging to identify areas of the brain involved in categorization at different ages in infancy. This project will have broader impacts by providing insight into long-standing debates about the basic nature of categorization throughout the life-span and by providing many important training opportunities. Several graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in developmental cognitive neuroscience, which will increase the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Additionally, the research team will actively engage in community outreach to increase public scientific literacy and public engagement with science.  

This project has three major aims that will be addressed in two experiments on 6-, 9-, and 12-month-old infants. Aim 1 is to determine the effects of attention on infant categorization of faces and objects, using simultaneous measures of heart rate changes associated with attention and electroencephalogram (EEG) measures of attention and categorization. Aim 2 is to determine how learning conditions affect infant attention and categorization, by varying the learning conditions infants experience prior to EEG testing. Aim 3 is to determine which areas of the brain are involved in categorization in infancy, using computational modeling of EEG data.  Infants are expected to show enhanced brain activity involved in categorization during attention, and areas of prefrontal cortex are expected to be involved in categorization only in older infants with more advanced categorization skills.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The infancy period is characterized by rapid gains in the development of selective attention and categorization. These fundamental cognitive processes are critically important for processing information efficiently and responding appropriately to events that occur in our everyday lives. Across the first year of life after birth, infants demonstrate increased voluntary control of attention as well as increasing specificity in their ability to categorize people, objects, and events. This project examined the development of categorization from 6 to 12 months of age. Electroencephalogram (EEG) measures of attention and categorization were used to examine infant attention and categorization of both human and non-human faces. Past research has shown that infants get better at processing human faces at the individual level with increasing age, but they get worse at processing monkey faces at the individual level with increasing age. This may be tied to the development of categorization. Older infants may shift to categorizing non-human faces instead of processing them at the individual level. We also examined the impact of initial learning conditions on infants’ ability to process and categorize human and non-human faces. Finally, computational modeling of the EEG was used to o determine areas of the brain involved in categorization of faces in infancy.

 

Our results indicate that by 9 months of age, infants begin to categorize non-human faces, but they continue to process human faces at the individual level regardless of whether the human face is from their own race or from another race. Infants showed enhanced processing of human faces when they were only shown a single human face during initial learning instead of seeing multiple faces from a single category or race. In contrast, infants showed enhanced processing of monkey faces when they were shown multiple monkey faces from the same category or species during initial learning instead of only a single face. The results of our computational modeling indicated that infants used similar brain regions for processing human and monkey faces. Brain regions involved in basic categorization (i.e., parahippocampal gyrus) were found to be active when infants were processing both human and monkey faces. However, infants showed increased specialized activity within brain regions associated with face processing (i.e., fusiform face area) when processing human faces that was not found when infants were processing monkey faces. These findings provide significant insight into the early development of face processing and categorization in infancy. Additionally, over a dozen students received training in advanced developmental cognitive neuroscience techniques which contributes to the future of the field and increased the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM. Community outreach associated with the project increased public scientific literacy in the local community. 

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2023
Modified by: Gregory D Reynolds
